questions.question: A virus is a piece of self-replicating code embedded within another program.
Phreaks and hackers are terms used to describe individuals who protect computer networks.
Denial-of-service attacks are a type of network security threat.
Online voting is not related to network security.
The increasing use of computers has led to a decrease in the importance of computer security.
Email and web surfing are examples of computer utilities.
Hard disks can be associated with program files.
Email attachments are not a common way for viruses to spread.
Diskettes or CDs are not used to spread viruses.
Files downloaded from the Internet can spread viruses.
Commercial antivirus software is not effective against viruses.
Few people keep their antivirus software up-to-date.
Worms are self-contained programs that spread through computer networks.
Worms do not exploit security holes in networked computers.
Code Red is a famous worm.
Robert Tappan Morris, Jr. created the Internet Worm.
The graduate student released the worm from a Cornell computer.
Infected computers became unresponsive or kept crashing.
Morris was expelled from Cornell.
Morris received 3 years' probation and 400 hours of community service.
Morris had to pay $150,000 in legal fees and fines.
Morris violated property rights of organizations.
Morris was wrong to have released the Internet worm.
Trojan horse is a program with benign capabilities.
Morris did not gain access to others' computers without permission.
Organizations did not learn of security errors from Morris's actions.
A Trojan horse replicates itself.
A Remote Access Trojan (RAT) gives attackers access to a victimâ€™s computer.
RAT servers are typically found in files downloaded from Usenet sites.
Attackers usually hide Trojan horses in games and small programs.
A bot is a software program that responds to commands from a user.
Some bots support legitimate activities.
All bots support illegitimate activities.
Distributing spam is a legitimate activity supported by bots.
System administrators play a key role in defensive measures.
Authentication is determining that a user has permission to perform a particular action.
A firewall monitors packets entering and leaving a local area network.
A packet filter accepts packets from any computer on the Internet.
The original meaning of 'hacker' dates back to the 1950s.
Hackers are often described as risk-takers.
The hacker ethic promotes the mistrust of authority.
The hacker ethic discourages the free exchange of information.
Hackers value decentralization.
Hackers aim to make systems do something never done before.
The text emphasizes skills over degrees and positions.
The text suggests a pessimistic view of technology.
The meaning of 'hacker' has remained the same over time.
Dumpster diving refers to looking through garbage for information.
Social engineering involves manipulating people to gain confidential information.
Social engineering involves manipulating someone within an organization to access confidential information.
Modern use of hacking is always for beneficial purposes.
Computer break-ins refer to unauthorized access to computer systems.
Destroying databases is not considered a malicious activity.
Stealing confidential personal information is a form of cybercrime.
Phone phreaking is the practice of manipulating the phone system to make free calls.
A phone phreak is someone who pays for all their phone calls.
One popular method of phone phreaking is stealing long-distance telephone access codes.
Guessing long-distance telephone access codes is not a method used in phone phreaking.
A 'blue box' is used to get free access to long-distance calls.
Access codes are posted on pirate boards by phreaks to share codes and credit card numbers.
Accessing an Internet computer without authorization is an example of a legal activity.
Transmitting a virus or worm is considered an illegal activity.
Trafficking in computer passwords is a legal activity.
Intercepting a telephone conversation, email, or any other data transmission is illegal.
Accessing stored email messages without authorization is considered unauthorized access.
Adopting another identity to carry out a legal activity is considered unethical.
Denial-of-service attacks aim to improve a server's ability to respond to clients.
Denial-of-service attacks disrupt a server's ability to respond to legitimate users.
About 4,000 Web sites are attacked each week by denial-of-service attacks.
A single person can harm a huge organization through a trical attack.
Asymmetrical attacks may prove popular with terrorists.
Mafia boy2000 targeted companies like Amazon, Yahoo, CNN, eBay, and Dell.
The 2000 U.S. Presidential election was closely contested.
Florida was not a pivotal state in the 2000 U.S. Presidential election.
Most Florida counties used keypunch voting machines in the 2000 U.S. Presidential election.
Two voting irregularities in the 2000 U.S. Presidential election were traced to keypunch voting machines.
Benefits of Online Voting include more people voting
Online voting would result in votes being counted more slowly
Electronic votes eliminate ambiguity
Online voting costs more money
Online voting can eliminate ballot box tampering
Software can prevent accidental over-voting
Software cannot prevent under-voting caused by poor ballot design
Online voting gives an unfair advantage to those with home computers.
It is easier to keep voter privacy in online voting systems.
The system records the ballot but not the identity of the voter.
Online voting reduces opportunities for vote-selling.
Online voting systems are not susceptible to DDoS attacks.
The security of an election depends on the security of home computers in online voting.
Online voting systems are susceptible to redirection to fake vote servers.
You are redirected to a fake server to obtain credentials and vote on your behalf from the actual site.
